narration.#text:
Welcome to the Professional eSPK lesson. The purpose of this lesson is to improve communication in the workplace by learning how to communicate effectively with the appropriate communication tool.

Click Next to see how eSPK savvy you already are.

gPremise.#text: Test your netiquette skills by categorizing the communication scenarios below. After reading each example, click Professional or Unprofessional on the right.

html5Text.#text:
What Is Your Modus Communicandi?

PROFESSIONALUNPROFESSIONAL

Test your netiquette skills by categorizing the communication scenarios below. After reading each example, tap Professional or Unprofessional.

SCENARIO 1
Bob sent an instant message to a coworker before leaving for the day. He said, “thx 4 ur help 2day ;) BRB”.
(A) Professional(B) Unprofessional
SCENARIO 2
Karen left a voicemail for her boss. “Hi Tom it’s Karen. I came down with a bad cold and won’t be able to come into work today.  I’ll let you know this afternoon if I’m able to come in tomorrow. You can reach me at #. Good-bye.”
(A) Professional(B) Unprofessional
SCENARIO 3
Kim participated in a conference call from home in his pajamas. The meeting went well and the client was happy with the progress Kim was making on their project.
(A) Professional(B) Unprofessional
SCENARIO 4
John felt very good about the webinar he hosted from work at work. He spent 10 minutes giving a thorough introduction of his role in the company and filled the remaining time with a powerfully packed sales presentation.
(A) Professional(B) Unprofessional
SCENARIO 5
Madison sent a text message reminder to her sales team. “Don’t forget lunch today, 1 pm @ Gandolfos”.
 (A) Professional(B) Unprofessional

page.title: What Is Your Modus Communicandi?
page.Qstn1: Bob sent an instant message to a coworker before leaving for the day. He said, “thx 4 ur help 2day ;) BRB”.
page.Qstn2: Karen left a voicemail for her boss. “Hi Tom it’s Karen. I came down with a bad cold and won’t be able to come into work today.  I’ll let you know this afternoon if I’m able to come in tomorrow. You can reach me at #. Good-bye.”
page.Qstn3: Kim participated in a conference call from home in his pajamas. The meeting went well and the client was happy with the progress Kim was making on their project.
page.Qstn4: John felt very good about the webinar he hosted from work at work. He spent 10 minutes giving a thorough introduction of his role in the company and filled the remaining time with a powerfully packed sales presentation.
page.Qstn5: Madison sent a text message reminder to her sales team. “Don’t forget lunch today, 1 pm @ Gandolfos”.
page.err1: Incorrect. Bob’s coworker is confused. Was Bob really grateful or ";)", just kidding? Is Bob gone for the day or will he "BRB", be right back?
page.err2: Karen's message is a professional voicemail because it is informative and concise.
page.err3: Incorrect. This would’ve been unprofessional if it was a videoconference.
page.err4: Incorrect. Lengthy introductions start the webinar off on a boring note.
page.err5: Incorrect. Short reminders that are clear and specific are a good use of text messaging.

narration.#text:
How do you feel you did?

As with any written scenario, there’s definitely room for interpretation.

Unless we’re speaking to a person face-to-face, correctly interpreting body language, and verifying the message, we’re shortcutting our communication and leaving room for misunderstanding and conflict.

This lesson will help you avoid the most common pitfalls associated with today’s most popular communication tools and give you some helpful tips on accepted technology etiquette.

popup_instruction.#text: Before you decide which device to use to communicate, consider your audience. Click each section of the Venn Diagram to explore your audience in more detail.

circle1.#text: If your meeting is live, make sure you schedule the meeting at a convenient time for your audience. Also, if your business takes you abroad don’t assume all participants speak English.
circle1.label: Demographics

circle2.#text: Do your homework and learn a little about your audience’s culture. You may be surprised how saying, "Hello" in your audience’s native tongue breaks down communication barriers and builds a relationship of trust. (www.inkdrop.net/dave/news.html, translate.google.com)
circle2.label: Culture

circle3.#text: Ask yourself why your audience wants to listen to your message and don’t stray too far off its intended purpose.
circle3.label: Purpose

circle4.#text: Be sensitive to gender when using analogies, examples, and media. If your audience can’t relate to how you’re presenting your message, they’ll be less likely to listen.
circle4.label: Gender

circle5.#text: The best way to improve your professional communication is to understand the limits and strengths of your personal communication style. (www.communication-styles.com/communication-style-survey-instructions.html)
circle5.label: Comm. Style

narration.#text:
Before you decide which device to use to communicate, consider your audience. Click each section of the Venn Diagram to explore your audience in more detail.

Click Start to begin.

html5Text.#text:
Know Your Audience

Asking the Right Questions
Before you decide which device to use to communicate, consider your audience.

Demographics
If your meeting is live, make sure you schedule the meeting at a convenient time for your audience. Also, if your business takes you abroad don’t assume all participants speak English.

Culture
Do your homework and learn a little about your audience’s culture. You may be surprised how saying hello in your audience’s native tongue breaks down communication barriers and builds a relationship of trust.
(www.inkdrop.net/dave/news.html, translate.google.com).

Purpose
Ask yourself why your audience wants to listen to your message and don’t stray too far off its intended purpose.

Gender
Be sensitive to gender when using analogies, examples, and media. If your audience can’t relate to how you’re presenting your message, they’ll be less likely to listen.

Communication Style
The best way to improve your professional communication is to understand the limits and strengths of your personal communication style.

narration.#text:
It’s important to take some time to learn how to work your device before you start using it professionally. Check out your user manual, online forums, YouTube demonstrations, or ask a friendly coworker.

Make sure your audience can receive your message and that your device is ready and reliable.

If you don’t have control over what device is going to be used during the meeting, ask if you can try it out before the meeting or talk to an IT person to make sure you know how it works and what connections or devices are compatible.

For instance, for a projector, identify which laptop connection VGA/DVI/HDMI/ADC or mini-DVI that you need. Do the same for your speaker system or microphone, because audio from laptops is never loud enough. And, don’t forget your trusty presentation pointer.

If you’re using a Smart Board, begin by connecting the smart cable to the USB port on your computer. Then, calibrate the touch points and remember to put down the pen when you want to drag things.

For webinars, make sure your audience can download the necessary software and all participants have a reliable internet connection. Know how to share your screen…, webcam…, and turn on and off the audio. If you’re planning on using any of the added features like polling…, changing presenter…, or markup, practice so your transitions will be smooth.

And for mobile devices, know how to silence the ringer…, mute a call…, and DON’T text and drive. Remember, before you tap send, review your mobile message twice because you’re 2 times as likely to make a clerical error.

intro.#text:
Do you have virtual office space in Second Life yet, or do you have your Bluetooth permanently attached to your ear?

To be environment friendly when communicating professionally means to be aware of what’s around you and who can hear you or your device.

In this interaction you'll explore how to be environmentally friendly by clicking on each of the circles. Click start to begin.

cir1.#text:
Alerts

When working within earshot of other people, turn off your audio alerts. As entertaining as you may think your creative sounds are, other people will quickly get annoyed when they hear "whoosh" or "ding" multiple times throughout the day.

Visual alerts and silent mode are much more environmentally freindly.
cir1.label: Alerts

cir2.#text:
Video Conferencing

• Do a quick mirror check to make sure you’re presentable

• Wear appropriate attire that does not distract

• Remove any distractions from your background

• Reduce as much surrounding commotion as possible before beginning:

- Close doors

- Turn off ringers

- Put your dog out

HowStuffWorks -

Rain Forest Video Conference
cir2.label: Video Conferencing

cir3.#text:
Email/Instant Messaging (IM)

• Respond in a reasonable time frame

• Change your availability status or add an "Out-of-Office" response

• Save emotional communication for face-to-face

• Consider the length:

- IM = 1-2 sentences max

- email = 2-3 paragraphs max

- attachment = 4+ paragraphs, 2 MB max (ask permission to send anything larger or send them a link for downloading)
cir3.label: Email/Instant Messaging (IM)

cir4.#text:
Screen Sharing

• Consider your desktop pictures or icons before sharing your screen with a client

- Hide propriotary information

- Use full screen to avoid distractions

• Close all documents and applications that will not be shared

- Turn off IM or other pop-up messaging

• Screen savers can be entertaining but probably won't help you promote your message
cir4.label: Screen Sharing

cir5.#text:
Texting

• Use silent mode when other people are around

• Don’t use txtspk in the workplace

• Don’t text and drive

• Don’t text and walk in public

Texting is becoming one of the most popular methods of communication because of its convenience. For that reason, it is important that we are considerate of others when sending and receiving text messages.
cir5.label: Texting

html5Text.#text:
Environmentally Friendly

How Your Communication Effects Others
Do you have virtual office space in Second Life yet, or do you have your Bluetooth permanently attached to your ear? To be environment friendly when communicating professionally means to be aware of what’s around you and who can hear you or your device.

Alerts
When working within earshot of other people, turn off your audio alerts. As entertaining as you may think your creative sounds are, other people will quickly get annoyed when they hear "whoosh" or "ding" multiple times throughout the day.

Visual alerts and silent mode are much more environmentally friendly.

Video Conferencing

  • Do a quick mirror check to make sure you’re presentable
  • Wear appropriate attire that does not distract
  • Remove any distractions from your background
  • Reduce as much surrounding commotion as possible before beginning
    • Close doors
    • Turn off ringers
    • Put your dog out

Texting

  • Use silent mode when other people are around
  • Don’t use txtspk in the workplace
  • Don’t text and drive
  • Don’t text and walk in public

Texting is becoming one of the most popular methods of communication because of its convenience. For that reason, it is important that we are considerate of others when sending and receiving text messages. 

Screen Sharing

  • Consider your desktop pictures or icons before sharing your screen with a client
  • Screen savers can be entertaining but may distract your audience



Email/Instant Messaging (IM)

  • Respond in a reasonable time frame
  • Change your availability status or add an "Out-of-Office" response
  • Save emotional communication for face-to-face
  • Consider the length:
    • IM = 1-2 sentences max
    • email = 2-3 paragraphs max
    • attachment =  4+ paragraphs, 2 MB max (ask permission to send anything larger or send them a link for downloading)

narration.#text:
Do you have virtual office space in Second Life yet, or do you have your Bluetooth permanently attached to your ear?

To be environment friendly when communicating professionally means to be aware of what’s around you and who can hear you or your device.

In this interaction you'll explore how to be environmentally friendly by clicking on each of the circles. Click start to begin.

pText.#text: This page contains an external activity. When you are ready to begin, click the Start button.

page.title: Test Your Professional eSPK

printMessage.#text: You've completed the quiz! You can use the buttons below to print your results, email your results, or review and retake the quiz.

introText.#text:
The purpose of this quiz is to help you determine if you have mastered the objectives in the Professional eSPK lesson:

• Identify the best communication device to use in a given scenario

• Recognize how you can communicate better by knowing your personal communication style

• Categorize communication as professional or unprofessional

• Choose the best ways to email professionally

Note: During the quiz the Back button will be disabled, you will only be able to answer each question once, you must score 80% to pass, and you can retake the quiz after you review your results.
introText.heading: Professional eSPK Quiz

evalPrompt.#text: Click Check Answer when you are done.

incorrectFeedback.#text: No. Texting is the only method of communication that would not be appropriate in this scenario.

questionText.#text: Click the image to assess your audience. If you know they are from a different country, are interested in learning about your company and product, which mode(s) of communication will be appropriate to use?

initPrompt.#text: Click True or False then click Check Answer.

correctFeedback.#text: That's right, knowing your communication style will help you communicate more professionally.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. Knowing your communication style will help you communicate more professionally.

questionText.#text: True or False: Knowing your communication style strength and weaknesses will help you communicate more professionally. For example, if your style is Controller, you can communicate better by listening more, allowing time for small talk, and showing interest in your audience.

evalPrompt.#text: Click Check Answer when you are done, or Reset to start over.

incorrectFeedback.#text: Incorrect. All of these are things you should test before giving your presentation.

questionText.#text: Click all the items you should test before giving a boardroom presentation with a laptop and projector.

distractor.#text: Power off your phone when it is not in use.
distractor.iFeedback: No. Though this will save power, it will not help communicate professionally.

distractor.#text: Be aware of what's around you when you're communicating.
Dispose of your cell phone battery at an approved recycling facility.
distractor.iFeedback: No. Though this will help save our earth, it will not help you communicate more professionally.
No. Only one of the other answers is correct.

questionText.#text: What does it mean to be environmentally friendly when communicating professionally?

textelement.#text: • Using mute when listening in on a webinar.
• Humorous desktop picture visible during screen share
• Answer text messages while in a meeting with a client
• Reduce background noise before video conference
• Audio alerts in the workplace are OK if they’re quiet

questionText.#text: Categorize each communication example as Professional or Unprofessional.

correctFeedback.#text: That's right, you should play it safe and test your presentation on the conference center devices before presenting.

incorrectFeedback.#text: You missed something. You should play it safe and test your presentation on the conference center devices before presenting.

evalPrompt.#text: Click Check Answer when you are done typing your response.

questionText.#text: You were just asked to give a PowerPoint presentation at a seminar. What should you do to prepare if you have to use the conference center’s laptop, projector, and speaker system for your presentation?

distractor.#text: Don’t send anything you don’t want printed and shared.
Ask email recipients if it’s OK before sending large email attachments.
Using “please” and “thank you” are too formal for emails.
Your signature is a good place to add additional notes or an added sales pitch.
Using email is a good idea if you are too emotional to communicate face-to-face.
Always review your email before clicking send because your intelligence will be judged by how well or poorly you write.

questionText.#text: Select all the ways that you can improve your professional communication with email.
